title: Elasticsearch 7.x support
body:
### What Grafana version are you using?
6.0.0 beta 3
### What datasource are you using?
Elasticsearch 7.0.0 beta 1
### What OS are you running grafana on?
Ubuntu
### What did you do?
After upgrading a Elasticsearch cluster from 6.6 to 7.0 beta 1, I can no longer add new indices as seperate datasources to grafana, due to the following error:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14551965/53301544-1c997600-384c-11e9-9eb6-b484183d70e0.png)

However, current data sources that were created when the cluster was 6.6.0 now no longer work, all charts display the following error:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14551965/53301565-45217000-384c-11e9-9104-bd96d36f738c.png)


Some useful F12 sceenshots to help:
1. Response when using old data sources after upgrading to Elasticsearch 7.0:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14551965/53301581-6aae7980-384c-11e9-8f35-161cd7468830.png)

2. Response when trying to create new data sources that are 7.0:
the _mapping Json is the following:
```
{"logging-2019.02.24":{"mappings":{"properties":{"@timestamp":{"type":"date"},"@version":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}},"Host-City":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}},"Host-Country-Code":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}},"Host-Env":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}},"Host-Type":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}},"HostName":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}},"Log-Event":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}},,"host":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}},"port":{"type":"long"},"type":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}}}}}}
```
Which clearly shows the @timestamp field as being of type 'date', even though grafana complains that @timestamp field does not exist

What Grafana version are you using?

6.0.0 beta 3

What datasource are you using?

Elasticsearch 7.0.0 beta 1

What OS are you running grafana on?

Ubuntu

What did you do?

After upgrading a Elasticsearch cluster from 6.6 to 7.0 beta 1, I can no longer add new indices as seperate datasources to grafana, due to the following error:

However, current data sources that were created when the cluster was 6.6.0 now no longer work, all charts display the following error:

Some useful F12 sceenshots to help:

  1. Response when using old data sources after upgrading to Elasticsearch 7.0:

  2. Response when trying to create new data sources that are 7.0:
    the _mapping Json is the following:

{"logging-2019.02.24":{"mappings":{"properties":{"@timestamp":{"type":"date"},"@version":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}},"Host-City":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}},"Host-Country-Code":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}},"Host-Env":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}},"Host-Type":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}},"HostName":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}},"Log-Event":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}},,"host":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}},"port":{"type":"long"},"type":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}}}}}}

Which clearly shows the @timestamp field as being of type 'date', even though grafana complains that @timestamp field does not exist

However, current data sources that were created when the cluster was 6.6.0 now no longer work, all charts display the following error:

Some useful F12 sceenshots to help:


Response when using old data sources after upgrading to Elasticsearch 7.0:



Response when trying to create new data sources that are 7.0:
the _mapping Json is the following:


{"logging-2019.02.24":{"mappings":{"properties":{"@timestamp":{"type":"date"},"@version":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}},"Host-City":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}},"Host-Country-Code":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}},"Host-Env":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}},"Host-Type":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}},"HostName":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}},"Log-Event":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}},,"host":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}},"port":{"type":"long"},"type":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}}}}}}

Which clearly shows the @timestamp field as being of type 'date', even though grafana complains that @timestamp field does not exist

node.body: Regarding max_concurrent_shard_requests the semantics has changed to be the maximum and now defaults to 5 instead of 256: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/7.0/breaking-changes-7.0.html#_semantics_changed_for_literal_max_concurrent_shard_requests_literal
node.bodyText: Regarding max_concurrent_shard_requests the semantics has changed to be the maximum and now defaults to 5 instead of 256: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/7.0/breaking-changes-7.0.html#_semantics_changed_for_literal_max_concurrent_shard_requests_literal
node.bodyHTML: Regarding max_concurrent_shard_requests the semantics has changed to be the maximum and now defaults to 5 instead of 256: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/7.0/breaking-changes-7.0.html#_semantics_changed_for_literal_max_concurrent_shard_requests_literal

bodyParsed.sent: Regarding max_concurrent_shard_requests the semantics has changed to be the maximum and now defaults to 5 instead of 256: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/7.0/breaking-changes-7.0.html#_semantics_changed_for_literal_max_concurrent_shard_requests_literal

node.body:
Hey guys,

Elastic Stack v7 is now GA, some production cluster will be (or are already) upgraded.
Mine is now in full 7.0.0 (GA) and I encouter the exact same problem.

Basicly, Grafana seems to not support this new version of ElasticSearch.

Any idea when it'll be fixed?

node.body:
Same problem here. We upgraded our production cluster and now Grafana stopped working.

The problem did not occured in all of my indexes, though. I think it's related to the amount of data in each of them. Indexes that have small amount of data seems to work, but indexes with lots of documents seems to crash.

Also, when trying to save / edit Datasources, an error is thrown: `No date field named @timestamp found` (even though the field exists).

Also, when trying to save / edit Datasources, an error is thrown: No date field named @timestamp found (even though the field exists).

node.body: We're planning to fix this for Grafana v6.3 where stable is ~6 weeks forward, but will probably land in master/nightly earlier.

node.body:
As another person who forgot all about Grafana and broke their production dashboard by upgrading things without testing first (and I even have an ELK dev stack in Docker Swarm) I would love some hints on what I might be able to do to assist in testing any early releases of a fix for this?

I've had to embed a Kibana dashboard via an iframe for now.

node.body:
@alcidesv Wow thanks for the prompt response.  I've now built my own image based on that with extra plugins, etc and it's up and running.

I am pleased to confirm that it has solved my issue for the dashboards I have.  Many thanks for your efforts!
node.bodyText:
@alcidesv Wow thanks for the prompt response.  I've now built my own image based on that with extra plugins, etc and it's up and running.
I am pleased to confirm that it has solved my issue for the dashboards I have.  Many thanks for your efforts!

node.body:
I also tested the docker image.
The dashboards are now working again! Thanks, @alcidesv!

The only thing that appears to not be working is the alerting functionality, always returning: `Query Returned No Series (reduced to null/no value)`.

node.body: @PepeLopez this issue is open because official Grafana support does not currently exists for elasticsearch v7. The docker image above is a build of the ongoing work for adding support for elasticsearch v7 and have been built by the author of PR #16646. No alerting support in above image as far as I'm concern, but besides that it sort of works. Please try it out if you want and provide feedback, if any. Thanks
node.bodyText: @PepeLopez this issue is open because official Grafana support does not currently exists for elasticsearch v7. No alerting support in above image as far as I'm concern, but besides that it sort of works. Please try it out if you want and provide feedback, if any. Thanks

bodyParsed.sent: @PepeLopez this issue is open because official Grafana support does not currently exists for elasticsearch v7.
The docker image above is a build of the ongoing work for adding support for elasticsearch v7 and have been built by the author of PR #16646.
No alerting support in above image as far as I'm concern, but besides that it sort of works.
Please try it out if you want and provide feedback, if any.
Thanks

node.body: Any reason why this isn't being back-ported to a minor release?
node.bodyText: Any reason why this isn't being back-ported to a minor release?
node.bodyHTML: Any reason why this isn't being back-ported to a minor release?

bodyParsed.sent: Any reason why this isn't being back-ported to a minor release?

node.body:
1) Because the features is not implemented / completed yet
2) we normally don’t backport features and enhancements

Because the features is not implemented / completed yet
we normally don’t backport features and enhancements

node.bodyHTML:
@danielfariati Thanks for feedback. Fix for that been pushed to #16646, but currently docker image mentioned above have not been updated as far as I'm concerned.

@marefr I tested the code pushed to #16646. Everything (including alerts) seems to be working perfectly, now.
Thanks!

bodyParsed.sent: @danielfariati Thanks for feedback.
Fix for that been pushed to #16646, but currently docker image mentioned above have not been updated as far as I'm concerned.
@marefr  I tested the code pushed to #16646.
Everything (including alerts) seems to be working perfectly, now.
Thanks!

node.body:
I am using the latest nightly build of grafana to connect to ES 7.0.

**INFO[05-01|06:38:43] Starting Grafana                         logger=server version=6.1.6 commit=cf9cb45 branch=HEAD compiled=2019-04-29T13:29:28+0000**

While saving the datasource, it gives an error

**"no handler found for uri [/5/1/2019og0tam06-2019.04.14-000001/_mapping] and method [GET]"**

The request in the grafana log is recorded as follows. Looks like a jumbled up index name being used.

**INFO[05-01|06:49:03] Request Completed                        logger=context userId=1 orgId=1 uname=admin method=GET path=/api/datasources/proxy/1/5/1/2019og0tam06-2019.04.14-000001/_mapping status=400 remote_addr=xx.xx.xx.xx time_ms=2 size=119 referer=http://xxxxx:2000/datasources/edit/1/**

Following is my data source config.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/46110311/57008196-3f753d00-6ba3-11e9-944e-00f7d519b0a3.png)

node.body:
I encountered this today in Grafana v5.4.2 after upgrading our cluster (QA, thankfully!) to 7.1.1, and found a workaround, for existing datasources at least.

When I removed (blanked out) the value from `Max concurrent Shard Requests` and saved, Grafana gave the complaint about `No date field named ... found` as described by OP, but returning to my dashboards, they now work.

In the Query Inspector, I can see that `max_concurrent_shard_requests` is then not included in the `_msearch` metadata section. Copying the query into Kibana devtools, I can reproduce that it works without, and fails with this metadata field. I presumed first that it's simply no longer supported in Elasticsearch 7.x ... but going back through documentation versions for [_msearch](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/7.1/search-multi-search.html), I can't actually find any evidence that it _ever_ was - it seems to be intended as a _query parameter_, not to go in the metadata. How it worked previously might have been an accident. Or, did it ever work? Pre-7.0, Elasticsearch accepted unrecognised fields in the metadata, ignored them, and only even [logged them](https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/blob/6.8/server/src/main/java/org/elasticsearch/action/search/MultiSearchRequest.java#L248) if deprecation logging was enabled. [elasticsearch#35938](https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/pull/35938) turned that into the "not supported in the metadata section" error we see here.

> Regarding max_concurrent_shard_requests the semantics has changed to be the maximum and now defaults to 5 instead of 256

This is true, but is it relevant? The value being a couple of orders of magnitude out, in existing queries, might cause performance or stability trouble, but shouldn't fail the query.

I'm surmising that when the `Max concurrent Shard Requests` textfield in the Grafana datasource UI has a value, the query fails but Grafana isn't adequately error checking - the first thing it does is look for the requested timestamp field, and of course doesn't find it in the error response, so it pops its own error message.
node.bodyText:
I encountered this today in Grafana v5.4.2 after upgrading our cluster (QA, thankfully!) to 7.1.1, and found a workaround, for existing datasources at least.
When I removed (blanked out) the value from Max concurrent Shard Requests and saved, Grafana gave the complaint about No date field named ... found as described by OP, but returning to my dashboards, they now work.
In the Query Inspector, I can see that max_concurrent_shard_requests is then not included in the _msearch metadata section. Copying the query into Kibana devtools, I can reproduce that it works without, and fails with this metadata field. I presumed first that it's simply no longer supported in Elasticsearch 7.x ... but going back through documentation versions for _msearch, I can't actually find any evidence that it ever was - it seems to be intended as a query parameter, not to go in the metadata. How it worked previously might have been an accident. Or, did it ever work? Pre-7.0, Elasticsearch accepted unrecognised fields in the metadata, ignored them, and only even logged them if deprecation logging was enabled. elasticsearch#35938 turned that into the "not supported in the metadata section" error we see here.

Regarding max_concurrent_shard_requests the semantics has changed to be the maximum and now defaults to 5 instead of 256

This is true, but is it relevant? The value being a couple of orders of magnitude out, in existing queries, might cause performance or stability trouble, but shouldn't fail the query.
I'm surmising that when the Max concurrent Shard Requests textfield in the Grafana datasource UI has a value, the query fails but Grafana isn't adequately error checking - the first thing it does is look for the requested timestamp field, and of course doesn't find it in the error response, so it pops its own error message.
node.bodyHTML:
I encountered this today in Grafana v5.4.2 after upgrading our cluster (QA, thankfully!) to 7.1.1, and found a workaround, for existing datasources at least.

When I removed (blanked out) the value from Max concurrent Shard Requests and saved, Grafana gave the complaint about No date field named ... found as described by OP, but returning to my dashboards, they now work.

In the Query Inspector, I can see that max_concurrent_shard_requests is then not included in the _msearch metadata section. Copying the query into Kibana devtools, I can reproduce that it works without, and fails with this metadata field. I presumed first that it's simply no longer supported in Elasticsearch 7.x ... but going back through documentation versions for _msearch, I can't actually find any evidence that it ever was - it seems to be intended as a query parameter, not to go in the metadata. How it worked previously might have been an accident. Or, did it ever work? Pre-7.0, Elasticsearch accepted unrecognised fields in the metadata, ignored them, and only even logged them if deprecation logging was enabled. elasticsearch#35938 turned that into the "not supported in the metadata section" error we see here.

Regarding max_concurrent_shard_requests the semantics has changed to be the maximum and now defaults to 5 instead of 256

This is true, but is it relevant? The value being a couple of orders of magnitude out, in existing queries, might cause performance or stability trouble, but shouldn't fail the query.

I'm surmising that when the Max concurrent Shard Requests textfield in the Grafana datasource UI has a value, the query fails but Grafana isn't adequately error checking - the first thing it does is look for the requested timestamp field, and of course doesn't find it in the error response, so it pops its own error message.

bodyParsed.sent: I encountered this today in Grafana v5.4.2 after upgrading our cluster (QA, thankfully!)
to 7.1.1, and found a workaround, for existing datasources at least.

When I removed (blanked out) the value from Max concurrent Shard Requests and saved, Grafana gave the complaint about No date field named ... found as described by OP, but returning to my dashboards, they now work.
In the Query Inspector, I can see that max_concurrent_shard_requests is then not included in the _msearch metadata section.
Copying the query into Kibana devtools, I can reproduce that it works without, and fails with this metadata field.

I presumed first that it's simply no longer supported in Elasticsearch 7.x ... but going back through documentation versions for _msearch, I can't actually find any evidence that it ever was - it seems to be intended as a query parameter, not to go in the metadata.
How it worked previously might have been an accident.
Or, did it ever work?
Pre-7.0, Elasticsearch accepted unrecognised fields in the metadata, ignored them, and only even logged them if deprecation logging was enabled.
elasticsearch#35938 turned that into the "not supported in the metadata section" error we see here.
Regarding max_concurrent_shard_requests the semantics has changed to be the maximum and now defaults to 5 instead of 256
This is true, but is it relevant?
The value being a couple of orders of magnitude out, in existing queries, might cause performance or stability trouble, but shouldn't fail the query.

I'm surmising that when the Max concurrent Shard Requests textfield in the Grafana datasource UI has a value, the query fails but Grafana isn't adequately error checking - the first thing it does is look for the requested timestamp field, and of course doesn't find it in the error response, so it pops its own error message.

node.body: @hackery you'll need at least Grafana v6.2.0 for Elasticsearch 7.x support.

node.bodyHTML: @hackery you'll need at least Grafana v6.2.0 for Elasticsearch 7.x support.

What did you do?
After upgrading a Elasticsearch cluster from 6.6 to 7.0 beta 1, I can no longer add new indices as seperate datasources to grafana, due to the following error:
However, current data sources that were created when the cluster was 6.6.0 now no longer work, all charts display the following error:
Some useful F12 sceenshots to help:
Response when using old data sources after upgrading to Elasticsearch 7.0:
Response when trying to create new data sources that are 7.0:
the _mapping Json is the following:

{"logging-2019.02.24":{"mappings":{"properties":{"@timestamp":{"type":"date"},"@version":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}},"Host-City":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}},"Host-Country-Code":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}},"Host-Env":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}},"Host-Type":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}},"HostName":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}},"Log-Event":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}},,"host":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}},"port":{"type":"long"},"type":{"type":"text","fields":{"keyword":{"type":"keyword","ignore_above":256}}}}}}}
Which clearly shows the @timestamp field as being of type 'date', even though grafana complains that @timestamp field does not exist
